content.title: Atherosclerotic Renal Artery Stenosis
content.summary: Atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis (ARAS) is the most common cause of renovascular hypertension and ischemic nephropathy. While revascularization was once common, current evidence supports medical therapy for most patients with interventions reserved for specific clinical scenarios.
content.definition: Narrowing of the renal artery lumen by atherosclerotic plaque, typically involving the ostium and proximal segment, potentially causing renovascular hypertension and/or ischemic nephropathy

chronic_phase.renal_adaptation: Loss of renin-dependence, volume expansion predominates
chronic_phase.ischemic_nephropathy: Progressive parenchymal damage from chronic hypoperfusion
chronic_phase.glomerulosclerosis: Secondary changes from hypertension and hypoperfusion

features: Flash pulmonary edema with bilateral disease
Unexplained CKD with vascular risk factors

flash_pulmonary_edema.mechanism: Bilateral RAS leads to volume overload
flash_pulmonary_edema.significance: One of few indications with clear revascularization benefit

duplex_ultrasound.limitations: Operator dependent, body habitus, technical failure

CTA.advantages: High accuracy, assess aorta and branches

MRA.limitations: May overestimate stenosis, gadolinium in severe CKD

catheter_angiography.role: Gold standard, usually with planned intervention

revascularization_indications.current_consensus: Most patients managed medically based on ASTRAL, CORAL trials
potential_indications: Refractory heart failure with bilateral disease
Rapidly declining renal function attributable to RAS
Truly refractory hypertension despite optimal medical therapy

options.bypass: Rarely needed; complex anatomy, failed stent, aortic surgery

trial_evidence.ASTRAL: No benefit of revascularization over medical therapy for renal function or BP
trial_evidence.CORAL: No benefit for cardiovascular/renal events; criticized for patient selection

prognosis.after_stenting: Variable; depends on residual renal parenchymal function

definition.@value: Atherosclerotic narrowing of the renal artery causing renovascular hypertension and/or ischemic nephropathy

learning_objectives: Describe the pathophysiology of renovascular hypertension
List clinical clues suggesting atherosclerotic RAS
Identify indications for revascularization vs medical therapy
clinical_pearls: ASTRAL/CORAL: medical therapy equivalent to stenting for most patients
Flash pulmonary edema with bilateral RAS = strongest revascularization indication
Creatinine rise >30% on ACEi/ARB suggests hemodynamically significant RAS
PSV >200 cm/s or RAR >3.5 on duplex suggests significant stenosis
Most RAS is atherosclerotic and ostial; FMD is mid-vessel
